para.text: Data sets are managed through the

Data sets have a two-dimensional or three-dimensional array of values. In PHAST, these values are assigned either to elements or to nodes and the data sets can apply either to the entire grid or a projection of the grid in the top, front, or side views. (These values correspond to “properties” as used in section 4.2.1.3 of the PHAST manual (Parkhurst and others, 2004). In MODFLOW and WellFootprint, these values are assigned to cells in the entire grid or to cells in a projection of the grid or mesh in the top view. In SUTRA, these values are assigned either to elements or to nodes in the mesh or a projection of the mesh in the top view. In this report, “properties” do not necessarily refer to spatially distributed data.) This section describes each of the properties of a data set that the user can change.
All of the data sets are displayed in a tree-view control on the left side of the
dialog box. When a data set is selected in the tree-view. its properties are displayed in the controls on the right side of the
dialog box. The data sets include those required by
along with data sets that the user has created. If a data set is sometimes required by the model but is not being used in the current project, it is displayed in the tree control under
. Data sets that are required by the current model are under

. Each data set has several properties: its name, whether or not it is visible, type, orientation (top, front, side, or 3-D), where it is evaluated (nodes or elements), its units, its formula, and, for 2-D data sets, its interpolation method. For data sets used directly by a model (

), the name, type, orientation, and where it is evaluated cannot be changed. For data sets created by the user, these properties can be changed. For some data sets that are used directly by PHAST, the user can use a special PHAST-style interpolation method (p. 16).
To create a new data set, click the
dialog box. Clicking the Add button, adds a new data set at the end of the list. To delete a data set, select data set in the tree-view and then click on the
button. (Users cannot delete data sets that are used directly by a model.)

of a data set is used to identify it in formulas for other data sets and when exporting the corresponding model data set (if there is one). A name must begin with either the underscore character a letter in either upper- or lower-case characters. Subsequent characters must be the underscore character, letters in either upper- or lower-case characters, or the digits 0 through 9. Spaces are not allowed in the names of data sets. Data Set names are case insensitive. Thus, “A_NAME”, “a_name”, and “A_Name” are all equivalent. Unicode characters are allowed in data set names. However, when data set names are printed in comments in model input files, Unicode characters will be converted to ASCII characters.
Each data set must have a

that indicates what kind of data are stored in it. Valid types are "Real," "Integer," "Boolean," and "Text.” These types represent real numbers, integers, true/false values, and text, respectively. Most of the data sets built into ModelMuse are "Real" or "Integer.” The "Active" data set is "True/False.” No built-in data sets are "Text.”
of a data set determines the shape of a data set. The possible choices are
orientation has a single layer but multiple columns and rows. A data set with a
orientation has a single row but multiple columns and layers. A data set with a
orientation has a single column but multiple rows and layers. A data set with a
orientation has multiple columns, rows, and layers.
data sets can only be used with PHAST.
, then the values in the data set correspond to elements in the model grid and are evaluated at the centers of elements. If
then the values in the data set correspond to nodes in the model grid. For orientations of
, the data set values correspond to the elements or nodes in a 2-D projection of the model grid from above. Similarly for
, the data set values correspond to the elements or nodes in a 2-D projection of the model grid from the front or side, respectively.
of a data set are meant to serve as a reminder to the user. The units do not affect how values are computed except if the units are set to degrees or radians. See

of a data set is a mathematical expression that defines the value that will be applied to each location in a data set unless a value for that location is specified in some other way (such as being set by objects). A formula may be a simple numerical value or it can express much more complex relationships. See the section on
If a data set is a two-dimensional data set, it can use one of the 2-D
methods in conjunction with one or more objects to define the values of a data set. If an interpolation method is being used with a data set, the

edit box related to that interpolation method becomes enabled in the bottom part of the dialog box when the data set is selected. Seven interpolation algorithms are available in ModelMuse. From fastest to slowest these are

para.text: , the PEST Parameters tab will be visible for some data sets. The PEST Parameters tab has a single control, the
checkbox is checked, a new data set will be created when the
button is clicked. The new data set will have the same name as the data set for which

was checked except that "_Parameter_Names" will appended to the name. The new data set will be a text data set. The new data set is used to designate cells (MODFLOW) or nodes or elements (SUTRA) to which a particular PEST parameter will apply. If the data set for which the

checkbox is checked is a required data set, the values of the model input data set to which it corresponds will be updated by PEST during the parameter estimation process. If the data set for which the
checkbox is checked is not a required data set, it will be exported as an array whose values will be updated by PEST and whose values can be used in model features.
checkbox is checked, two more controls become enabled.
Define observations of data sets values

: If this checkbox is checked, you can define observations of values assigned to an input data set. For example, if you have a measurement of hydraulic conductivity at a location. You can use that as an observation to constrain the simulation. After checking the
Define observations of data sets values
checkbox and clicking "Apply", a new data set will be created. The new data set will have the same name as the data set for which
was checked except that "_Weight" will appended to the name. You can assign input data set observations by defining a positive value at any location in the "_Weight" data set.
Define observations of data sets values
checkbox is checked. If it is checked, the

can be used to merge observations that are within the search distance of one another. The observation supplied to PEST will have a value equal to the weighted average of all the individual data set values. The weight of the observation will be the average of all the individual weights for the individual data set values. If

is left at the default value of zero, any location where the "_Weight" data set is non-zero will define an observation for PEST. The benefit of merging observations is to prevent an excessive number of observations from being defined. If too many observations are defined, the amount of memory used by PEST can be prohibitive.
is provided for the use by the user. It is also displayed in the
dialog box. When importing new data sets, a comment for the data may be automatically generated describing the source of the data, the data range, or other information. (See also:
lists the names of the model input data sets correspond to the data set. The user can not assign the

for all cells checkbox will be enabled when the data set is selected. If the user checks this checkbox, the other controls related to PHAST-style interpolation will become enabled. See
In a new ModelMuse project, the only data sets present are those

. However, the user can create additional data sets for his or her own purposes. One reason to create a data set would be to use it in a formula for one of the data sets required by PHAST. For example, the user could create a
data set that represented the hydraulic conductivity of a particular geologic unit. It could then be used to assign Kx for just those elements that were part of that geologic unit. The
In MODFLOW models, some data sets are set using MODFLOW parameters, zone arrays and multiplier arrays instead of with formulas and objects. The parameters are defined in the
